sample.title: Inside South Africa's Deadly Mine Disaster | Bloomberg Investigates
sample.description:
In 2024, a government crackdown on illegal mining turned deadly in the South Africa town of Stilfontein. Hundreds of miners were trapped underground for months without food or water. Bloomberg Investigates follows the survivors as they recount their haunting experiences, and their fight for a rescue that came too late for many.

sample.title: How Warren Buffett Changed Investing Forever
sample.description:
Legendary investor Warren Buffett is retiring as Berkshire Hathaway's Chief Executive Officer at the end of the year. He‚Äôll hand the reins to Greg Abel, a longtime energy executive who was widely seen as his likely successor. Abel will take over Berkshire‚Äôs $1.2 trillion empire and its powerhouse stock portfolio, including Apple, Coca-Cola and American Express. Here‚Äôs how the ‚ÄúOracle of Omaha‚Äù transformed modern investing, and what‚Äôs next for the company he built.

(An earlier version of a thumbnail on this video incorrectly spelled Warren Buffett‚Äôs name.)

sample.title: Why Investors Think Loans Are About To Get Cheaper
sample.description:
At the conclusion of its final meeting in 2025, the Federal Reserve will release a forecast of future financial conditions. The Summary of Economic Projections will show where the Fed‚Äôs leadership expects to take interest rates over the coming years. The so-called ‚Äúdot-plot‚Äù foreshadows what Americans will pay for new mortgages, auto loans and other forms of credit.

sample.title: Why young grads are struggling to find jobs
sample.description:
Even as the U.S. economy adds jobs, there are fewer employment prospects for college graduates just starting out, as those armed with a newly minted diploma are facing one of the toughest job markets in a decade, studies show.

"Right now is a really difficult time to find a job," Cory Stahle, senior economist at Indeed Hiring Lab, told CNBC.

sample.title: Why beef prices are out of control in the U.S.
sample.description:
Beef prices are up around 15% compared to overall food inflation of about 3% in 2025. That's mainly due to the lowest U.S. cattle herds in nearly 75 years. Direct-to-consumer beef company Omaha Steaks gave CNBC a behind the scenes look at its operations to learn more about how beef has gotten so expensive and how companies are responding.

sample.title: What's the difference between all of the AI chips?
sample.description:
Nvidia‚Äôs Blackwell GPU sales are ‚Äúoff the charts‚Äù according to CEO Jensen Huang, but analysts see fast growth for custom AI chips, known as ASICs.

These smaller, cheaper, more narrowly focused AI chips are being designed in-house by Google, Amazon, Meta, Microsoft and OpenAI.

sample.title: Want To ‚ÄòInvest' In OpenAI or SpaceX? What To Know About Tokenization
sample.description:
Private companies like OpenAI and SpaceX have captured enormous investor enthusiasm in recent years, driving up their valuations. Yet because they‚Äôre privately held, they‚Äôve remained largely inaccessible to ordinary investors. Now a new approached called tokenization could change that by giving retail investors access to investments aligned with the performance of private companies. But despite its appeal, some worry that tokenizing private companies could be a way to bypass longstanding regulations meant to protect investors.

sample.title: Italian cuisine wins a place on UNESCO heritage list
sample.description:
Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni welcomed UNESCO‚Äôs decision to add Italian cuisine to its list of intangible cultural heritage, calling the move a recognition of the country‚Äôs identity and its global influence. She said Italy was the first nation to receive such an honor for its national culinary tradition, describing the designation as a boost for a sector she called central to the country‚Äôs culture and economy.

sample.title: LIVE: Sydney Harbour Bridge lights up for social media ban
sample.description:
Sydney Harbour Bridge lights up in Australia's national colours to mark the under 16s social media ban.

Australia has ordered 10 major platforms including TikTok, Alphabet's YouTube and Meta's Instagram and Facebook to block around one million users under the age of 16 or face massive fines.

Some 200,000 accounts have already been deactivated on TikTok alone, the government said, with "hundreds of thousands" to be blocked in the coming days.

Half a million displaced as Thailand-Cambodia clashes continue | BBC News
sample.description:
Border clashes between Thailand and Cambodia have extended for a third day, killing at least 10 people and displacing hundreds of thousands.
 
Both countries have blamed each other for re-igniting the fighting, which has seen air strikes and exchanges of artillery fire.
 
Thai officials said they evacuated more than 400,000 people, while Phnom Penh said 100,000 on the Cambodian side have been moved to shelters.

sample.title: Ukraine 'ready for elections' if partners guarantee security, Zelensky says | BBC News
sample.description:
Ukraine is "ready for elections", President Volodymyr Zelensky has said, after US President Donald Trump repeated claims Kyiv was "using war" to avoid holding them.

Zelensky's five-year term as president was due to end in May 2024, but elections have been suspended in Ukraine since martial law was declared after Russia's invasion.

Speaking to reporters following Trump's comments in a wide-raging Politico interview, Zelensky said he would ask for proposals to be drawn up which could change the law.

Elections could be held in the next 60 to 90 days if security for the vote was guaranteed with the help of the US and other allies, he said.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

sample.title: Donald Trump tells Ukraine it‚Äôs losing war with Russia and must accept peace deal | BBC News
sample.description:
President Trump has said Ukraine‚Äôs leader Volodymyr Zelensky has to start accepting that his country is losing its war with Russia.

Speaking in an interview he said Russia was much bigger and stronger than Ukraine and ‚Äúat some point size will win‚Äù.  He also criticised European leaders, calling them weak and saying they were not handling the war well.   

Trump called on Ukraine to hold presidential elections, suggesting that without them its government was not democratic. Ukraine‚Äôs President Zelensky suggested he was considering changing the  constitution to allow an election to take place while the country is under martial law. 

In Moscow, the Russian President Vladimir Putin has been awarding medals to soldiers who‚Äôve been fighting in Ukraine. 

Clive Myrie presents BBC News at Ten reporting by Sarah Smith in Washington, Jonathan Beale in Kyiv and Steve Rosenberg in Moscow. 

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
